title: "I'm a toxic player but it's Riot's fault"
body:
No, it's not Riot's fault.  The game can make you lose: feeders, 4v5s, those two Diamond players on the other team, those two "Silver" smurfs on the other team... lots of things can happen to make you lose.

The game cannot make you rage.  Take responsibility for your actions.

replies.body:
But but I don't control my own actions.   I can't help that others make me do it.  I am not responsible for the things I do.  It is always someone else's fault.    



Ok lets get real.   The OP is 100% accurate.
OP you are stupid!

Damn, you got me.  I guess, because I'm so enraged by that witty and accurate insult, I have no choice but to hire the Russians to hack your computer and replace all your pictures with vile obscenities.  It's not really my fault, it's the trolls.

Is this the legendary bronze V flamer, come from the depths of elo hell to end us all?

...

Nope. Just another noob. Carry on, people.
Eh, I thought it was funny.  I like to think there was some self-awareness on Niekuh's part.
We can hope.
"I'm toxic because X" doesn't mean it is X's fault. I'm toxic because of trolls. Sure, it's my own decision to be, but it still remains that is the reason lol.

Here's the thing: "I'm toxic because of trolls in my games" only absolves you of your responsibility if 100% of people react to trolls by becoming toxic.  They don't.  You're toxic because there are trolls in your games and you choose to react to them by becoming toxic.

If I'm driving behind someone who's doing 3mph below the speed limit and I honk my brain out, like, lean on the horn for some extended-duration honking, I might get pulled over (that's illegal in some places).  I can't get off by telling the officer "Well, I shouldn't get a ticket: you pulled me over because that asshole was driving too slow."  He might respond by saying "No, I pulled you over because you were honking.  Just because the car ahead is going too slow doesn't make you honk your horn."

Does that make sense?

He is not saying it justifies anything, he is just pointing out how you legitimately cannot say "I'm a toxic player but it's Riot's fault" is a flawed argument. It doesn't justify the raging or toxicity in any way, but it can be and often is a 100% accurate reason. You are arguing that Riot isn't why people rage, which isn't a consistent provable point. He never once brought anything about responsibility into this, only that you were wrong about what the cause can be. He is simply saying that your argument that "saying "you rage because of X" is invalid" is incorrect because causality is not in any way linked to responsibility in this scenario. In you example right here, the driver got pulled over got pulled over for honking his horn (equivalent to getting a chat restriction), however, whether he is justified in honking or not, the *cause*—the slow car in front of him (Riot, Trolls, Feeders, *insert reason to rage here*)—remains 100% true and accurate. I believe people when they say "I rage because of Riot for X reason", but that doesn't justify them, and you appear to be confusing two separate arguments (justification vs causality).

EDIT: Additionally, you also forget that people aren't saying they get restrictions and bans and want to blame Riot for them, they know it is because they rage, but that punishment is indirectly caused by Riot in the exact same way that the slow car in front of you indirectly caused you to get pulled over. You are never justified by the fact that something else caused it to happen, but pointing out the issue can help the officer pulling you over to make other corrections that help you not be in the situation to get pulled over in the first place.

You're making an important distinction between causation and responsibility.  What I'd like to point out is that, in the OP, I'm explicitly talking about responsibility.  Once a person is thinking in terms of "I chose to be toxic because X," I don't really care what X is, because they understand that they could've chosen differently: I hope they'll choose differently next time.  If someone says "I'm toxic because of trolls," I'm not going to respond with "trolls aren't a problem, you are," I'm going to respond with "trolls may be a problem, but it's your reaction to them that makes you toxic."

To put it another way, I don't care about the causes of toxicity.  Everyone has the option of not raging, so when they choose to rage, the responsibility is on them.

He is not saying it justifies anything, that's true.  What I'm worried about is what he's thinking.  If I asked him "do you feel bad about being toxic," would he say "no, I'm toxic because of trolls" or would he say "the trolls are horrible, but yeah, I could've done better not responding to them?"  If it's the second one, that's fine, momentary lapses of judgement are reasonable *as long as you understand that you had a lapse of judgement.*  If it's the first one, our toxic player is never going to try to change, because they don't believe it's something they can control.

And this is where I see hope in the boards, when we can have an honest and thoughtful discussion about a generally argument based topic (raging). I agree with what you said in the OP, and your points here, however, I don't think that SN2 Surpiser was necessarily addressing the issue from the same perspective as you, and I simply wanted to point out that for your response to make sense, you should have responded in kind, instead of bringing up responsibility when he was trying to look at a different aspect of the conversation. I really agree with the idea of "Lapses of judgement" when it comes to raging. Generally speaking, I don't rage. That is it. I may get mad at a match, but I almost never verbalize it in the chat box for the sake of not costing us a game or myself a ban. Sometimes though, I slip, and I type that 1 sentence into the chat, and a flame war starts. Usually in about 5 minutes I'm sitting there like "man, I just screwed up" and sometimes I catch myself sooner and immediately follow up with, "sorry, that was rude" and leave it at that. The important thing though like you said is being able to catch yourself and stop in the moment before you do more to hurt somebody else's experience.
Thank you for not being narrowed minded and down voting because you don't understand lol :D

Actually, the person driving 3mph would get pulled over before you would, but that's beside the point lol. Basically what jungler said is true, so I won't go into too much detail about it.

All I will add to the statement is that people don't really rage at others for losing lanes. They rage at the trolls in the game. Instead of trying to chat ban 5 people that 1 troll caused to rage, punishing that 1 person would cause toxicity to go down much further. Not saying toxicity is right or anything, but there are actual ways to help fix it, and chat banning everyone who points out mistakes people are making is not the way to go.

Trust me, the last thing I'm trying to say is that Riot's perfect.  If they asked me to list the issues I'd address, they'd get an e-mail that took an hour to read.  I wonder, are chat bans still handled by tribunal or does Riot have its own separate discipline system these days?  But yeah, I would support punishment for the first AFK/offensive language/whatever and less punishment for the people who get dragged into it.

There is no tribunal anymore. They took it down because reasons? and replaced it with a non-existent system. I literally asked for some insight into a chat ban that I received. I got the first one (well deserved) and played through it. At the end I was surprised to see an additional penalty that was 2x as long as the first. I wasn't toxic WHATSOEVER in my games, so naturally I was confused. I asked support guy, after a run around with some moron that only copy and pasted the same thing in every comment, I finally got a "behavior specialist". He opened with "it is important to note that you are not currently doing anything wrong". I said well wtf then rito guy (not word for word, but I was thinking it like this lol), you are telling me I am not doing anything wrong but still getting chat restricted, why? He said "the punishment is adjusting to your account". I said well, that doesn't make sense since you told me that I wasn't doing anything wrong still. What do you mean? He said, "the punishment is adjusting to the health of your account. I see that the health of your account is improving". By this point I was fairly frustrated, obviously, but was still nice about it. I said those two things don't make sense mr rito guy. You are telling me that my health is improving, and my punishment is adjusting to my account health level. Then why is the penalty I just recieved 2x as long? That literally makes no sense at all. He said, "sorry but we can't go into detail". Some support. After trying to get Lyte on the boards, he finally answers with "you told your teammate to 'calm the fuck down' because he was raging at one of your teammates". Yes. I got a 2x as large chat ban because I told a rager to calm down lol. #ritologic.

I've literally given up on the community in this game. Instead of giving help to teammates like "try to ward here" or "please don't fight your lane enemy when behind. Just play the tower farm game and wait for teammates" (because that gets you a "/all report X flaming toxic" and rito clearly doesn't look at why you're being reported, just that you are), I just wait and say "gj team" every couple of mins, even if we are down 0-15.
McAllister got most of that, but I would like to point out he said 3mph *below* speed limit, so he's going 57 instead of 60.

It might be partly Riot's fault actually.

Time for learning! Humans have a limited capacity for self-control/directed mental effort (aka Focus). The game requires so much concentration from some people that there isn't anything to filter the emotionally charged suggestions of the sub-conscience.

References and further reading:
*[Thinking, Fast and Slow](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thinking,_Fast_and_Slow)*

That is, it may be a difficult to avoid by-product of the game they chose to create. On the other hand, this quality is exactly what makes this genre of game so absorbing and enjoyable...

This is a very insightful comment!  Normally I've been downvoting people who claim it's Riot's fault, but the truth, as you know, is that there's a bit of nuance involved.  As someone who personally struggles with depression, I know full well the experience of being technically able to, say, take out the trash, but failing to make myself do it.  What's the difference between me sitting there in my PJs on trash night blaming my depression and Roids McRagerson the LoL player verbally abusing people and blaming it on limited self-control and provocation by trolls?

For once, I don't have a witty reply.  All I can say is that I generally find it within myself to do what I need to get done, and when I fall short, I can forgive myself and try to do better next time.  I've never been saying that every LoL player must maintain 100% sportsmanlike communication in all games, I'm saying that, when they fall short, they need to look inside for the reason they got salty in all-chat instead of blaming trolls, Rito and every other thing.

Oh, I'm totally on board with your perspective and also on a society level, rage-y outbursts are not acceptable. You are also totally correct in that there is more to it then just the capability to do something. Lots of external and/or short-term factors which a person should be able to identify ahead of playing a game like this and take preventative measures for (like not playing or using various ways to mitigate those factors before playing).

Also, I'll mention that the amount of focus/self-control a person has can be improved by practice (or is it exercise for your brain?). Whether this would translate to more control over emotions (including rage) or improved play (or both) is beyond me. Mastery over the various aspects of the game should also lessen the burden of focus but on the other hand the focus may just move to other aspects of the game like you see from the pros in [this video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZvRiA3aCgPI) concerning where their eyes are looking.

I would just like to congratulate the two of you for making a point and counterpoint without flipping out! You both are now officially the most Logical and Cool-headed people on the internet!

On a side note, While I agree humans are, quite frankly, shitty at self control, 4/5 the catalyst for people's rage really **isn't** the company behind the game, or the game's mechanics themselves. I tend to find that a Rager's rage is often caused by a mix of:

1. A Streak of Losses - This really is self-explanatory. What's more stressful than losing 1 match? How about 6? Or 10?

2. Simply not having a good day - This seems to be the most common one. Often If I'm having a bad day I'll actually avoid playing League. Some people, however, will hop on thinking "Maybe a quick match will help me feel better." And that might be true, if they actually won, but as it's been shown before, a Poor disposition/Generally negative feelings bog down one's gameplay and skill. So hopping on to play and blow off some steam from a bad day **COULD** simply make your day worse. and most likely lead to a scenario like #1.

3. Being stuck on "The Meta" - I'll admit that when someone Meta-breaks, I'm skeptical. On one hand, "Cool, they're trying something I've never seen! Maybe this is good!"
On the other hand, there's "Oh jeez, Syndra Jungle? I'm not really confident that will work."
Now, I'm not referring to seeing someone pick a bad pick and feeding horribly as "Being stuck on 'The Meta'". I'm Referring to Raging at someone *Before the match even starts* for choosing a champion not commonly used in the role they've taken, or choosing a different Lane-positioning than the "standard." (Such as Duo-top, solo bot. Or Duo-jungle and solo Lanes [Which worked better before the Rift update])
I understand the Skepticism, but I feel it's important to Remember to ***Separate your Skepticism from your rage.***

4. Playing Alone - Believe it or not, Soloqueue might actually be **bad** for your in-game performance, and in turn, your mood. When you have a friend playing with you, It's a lot less stressful. When you make a Mistake, you have someone else to re-assure you that you DON'T Suck. And this isn't even BEGINNING to touch on the Communication factor. It's practically a no-brainer that better communication = Better teamwork = Better Gameplay. Commonly, good friends playing together will Either be sitting nearby eachother, Using Skype/Curse/insertvoicechattingsoftware, and it's shown to be reliable. the communication is faster, you can talk with your mouth during combat, but you *can't* type during combat.
To sum it all up, Play with Friends. It's less stressful and overall both of you will perform better.

And if you have no friends... I'm really sorry. :c Have a free hug. {{champion:32}}

Thanks!  You can join the club.  Our stickers say "wouldn't it be nice if we were as loud as those people who get mad about everything."  I'm also with you 100% about playing with friends: I play with and without, but voice chatting with people who you know at least a little bit is huge.  If nothing else, if they DC, they can tell you how close they are to getting back in.

I'm sure focus isn't the only correlation between experience playing and rage potential.  People say some pretty brutal things to noobs, and when you spend 2/3 of the game dead because their Tryndamere instantly deletes you every time you walk out of base, you have plenty of time to take the bait.

Why, yes, I do hate Tryndamere, why did you ask...

It's still not even partly Riot's fault. If this game taxes one's capacity that much, then I have several suggestions:
1. Don't play this game. That's harsh but if you cannot both play a game and be a decent human being to the other players, you need to choose a different game.
2. Choose different priorities. Focus first on being non-toxic and give your residual attention to playing the game, rather than the other way around.  I like winning too but never at the expense of dehumanizing the other people playing the game.

I'm not *really* pointing a finger at them, but the nature of the game is part of the situation. Given that they are trying to adjust player behavior they will have to deal with the nature of humans. I suspect that Riot would first try to help players do number two as you have suggested. The new player experience could help lessen the burden of the game by providing experience (lessening the cognitive load) or proper framing (another concept from psychology). I would bet that their messages on the loading screen are likely trying to provide framing but were easier to implement. When **Baldur Odinson** replied to me above he suggested playing with friends which helps with number 2 as well.

For your number 1, however, there is an entire discussion hiding in that. I'll just say a few things.

1. I am simplifying to say so, but I agree. My experience shows that some activities are simply too complex and require too much focus based on a person's development level. For instance, my daughter simply cannot enjoy smash bros with me yet :(

2. The supportable cognitive load also changes with factors that fluctuate in the range of seconds and is not entirely under conscious control. This complicates the decision of whether you could forecast your ability to be a decent person for the duration of a game.

3.  Something negative in chat will be automatically processed by the subconscious regardless of how they consciously interpret it and that does change things. People who say that you should just have a thick skin about or just ignore the negative stuff people say or type are *grossly* ignorant of the way the human mind works.

4.  The Venn diagram of people who shouldn't play the game because it is too much for them but are also capable of recognizing that fact is a trivial faction of the total population of players.
If I don't manage to make time for a full reply later, I just wanted to let you know now that I appreciate your response. It was thoughtful, interesting, and well-written.

Hey, just noticing this from reading through the comments below, but I think there may be a disconnect between what you mean by "cannot make you rage" vs "cannot make you *want* to rage". The game certainly can make you rage in the sense that it can make you very angry, and that is what people are responding to, but all of your responses seem to indicate you want to emphasize that while it can make you *mad*, what you mean by rage is the actual act of verbally abusing oner players in your anger. If you maybe clarified that in the OP, I think you could get your discussion a little more focused in the direction you seem to want.
I can kick you in the testicles. My foot cant make you rage right?

It would make him feel pain, but what he feels beyond that is dependent on the person, and what he does is dependent on what choice he makes.  Keep in mind you are allowed to get angry while playing league, you just aren't supposed to type your anger out in the chat system (rage).

I rage a great deal, I rage about my team or about the enemy whooping my sorry backside. HOWEVER, I refuse to say much beyond, "Hey, stop doing that thing that's getting you killed." in chat. Found that I tend to do better in my games if I rage on the outside, but in chat I act all nice 'n stuff. Can't see why people would blame the game for their rage. For the most part I agree, it's not what happens, but how you react to it. That can be said for a lot, not just in League, but in life as well.

Yeah, Junglerboy16 pointed out to me that I was using "rage at" to mean "verbally abuse."  If you're just sitting there angry, there's nothing wrong with that except for the fact that you're not having fun.

I know where you're coming from, and I know you are talking about a different kind of player, but I actually fit in this category.  I started playing this game as a completely non-toxic player.  After 3 years of dealing with endless assholes,spoiled children, and trolls, I just don't have the patience for it anymore.  Now I have to quit playing this game most nights because I lose my cool and just can't deal with the overloaded community of raging griefers.  I have been using the report system since I started, but the community has only gotten worse.  Riot only punishes the worst of the worst, and most of the punishments are laughable slaps on the wrist.  Do you think someone is going to take the time to stop and learn how to properly communicate with people because you gave them a big scary chat restriction?  They don't care.  Low priority queue?   Ooooohh you better be scared of waiting 5 whole extra minutes to play a game.  Disable ranked?  They just go troll normals till its back. 

You need to suspend or ban people entirely.  Some random spoiled kid likely doesn't even spend money on this game, so you lose exactly nothing from banning him, and you gain an improved community.  Spend long enough time with a no-nonsense tribunal, and people will stop losing their shit on everyone the instant anything goes wrong.  It is Riot's job to fix this, not mine.  I'm not the irresponsible parents of these kids, but you're forcing me to babysit them with leaverbuster and you want me to try teach them how to speak to another person when there is no way to communicate with them in the first place.  These things are not my responsibility, and I don't understand anyone thinking that they are.  Could I handle this better?  I'm sure its possible, but I also suffer from mental disabilities, the most important one being severe social anxiety disorder.  If someone attacks me, I generally lose it.  I can't help it most of the time because I have a medical condition, but most people seem to think every time I have a panic attack online that it's my fault, and that's just sad.  A platform was given to these random sociopaths to verbally assault people, and that's what it's being used for more often than not.  But it's my fault, right?  :P
That would apply if playing league were the issue, but it isn't, it's the trolls and such.  The game itself is wonderful fun when nobody is raging on each other, and that's how it should always be.

"I don't have to rage if things make me angry, but what if they make me REALLY angry?"

Yep, still don't have to rage.  Try taking the Enter key off your keyboard when the game starts.

I totally agree that the OP is accurate. I'm facing something of a dilemma, however. While I take it as a point of pride to vent to MYSELF (that is, I'll growl out while I'm playing but never take it out on my team-mates) I find myself getting a bit discouraged. While we do get little gifts here and there to encourage us to not be toxic and support our team-mates such as the mystery skin (here's hoping mine comes soon) I find myself in a position where even if I play well, an entire game can get thrown by the actions of a single individual. In my last game for example, our Tryndamere went 1/10/1--and had fed five times by the seven minute mark. Even after encouraging him to play cautiously, using smart pings, etc, it didn't make much of a difference.

Now, I didn't flame--I didn't even make a sarcastic comment like "those throws though". But I was frustrated, and even though I said "Good game, well played" after surrendering, I still felt a bit crushed inside. Being toxic helps nobody--it just vents poison. But maybe my question can be answered best by a more experienced player. That is, how do you constructively deal with a game like that? If it isn't a matter of team composition, or individual skill, how do you deal with a thrown game?

The only real solution I've found is taking a break, and coming back a bit later. But it seems to be an unfortunate trend that, at least where I am now, it is difficult to eke out a victory if even one person is overly new or unskilled. How do you handle that? I personally always try to support or jungle, but I almost feel a kind of learned helplessness at points.

I think this may help some people out. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tilt_(poker)

Raging at people can cause people to go on Tilt and you being on Tilt can cause you to rage at people.  If you are not going into your Ranked games with a "Meh, I could lose a game" attitude, you are setting yourself up for a loss.

As for AFK's and trolls, there is not really much Riot can do about them.  It is much easier to break and abuse something than to create something.  We as a community need to be better.  We need to let things go, and realize that Normal, Placement, Promo, etc. match its just a game and we shouldn't let it control us.

"I kill him, because he forced me to do that"
it's not his fault...
Statistically speaking there is more of a chance of a feeder, afk, or troll being on the enemy team.  Unless of course you are it.
Statistically speaking, you're more likely to get an opponent that's above your skill level on the enemy team than to get a skilled ally.
